posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
When disabling our logging system, values updated every 20ms as expected. However, enabling the system resulted in updates every 60ms, contrary to expectations since feedback should post periodically at the set interval (defaulting to 20ms). Early in the season, we published values via the Shuffleboard API within our execute method due to its readability and reduced logging errors. Later, switching to Feedback improved code readability and reliability.

Switching to Feedback caused values to update consistently at approximately 20ms during the week three competition, aligning with our previous behavior. However, in later competitions, components' loop times ranged from 0.1ms to 10ms, with the @feedback timer averaging 0.000001 seconds per cycle. Notably, during later competitions, the @feedback timer varied between 0.02 and 0.04 seconds per cycle, indicating double or triple the allocated loop time despite similar component cycle times.

While teams using Feedback sporadically experienced minimal impact, the Shuffleboard API showed negligible performance overhead. This suggests Feedback may be significantly slower, conflicting with expectations of comparable performance. Despite efforts, the root cause remains unclear, prompting questions about @feedback functionality or potential misuse.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: That’s really weird. There were no magicbot changes after kickoff. The amount of time involved (200–400ms) suggests a slow CAN API call within a feedback function.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Accessing the bot has made comprehensive testing challenging, but what can be confirmed is that logging the pitch and roll readings from our gyro resulted in unbearable loop overruns, prompting immediate code adjustments just before the event. Interestingly, `drivetrain.py` exhibited the longest periodic time among all components, raising questions about whether the gyro's CAN API call caused the issue.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
After reviewing some log files, it appears that the CAN API might be causing issues. The NetworkTables values are ordered by timestamp, allowing me to analyze response times effectively. Tracking min and median delays helped identify patterns.

In analyzing existing data in memory, I found typical response times for non-CAN calls, such as PID outputs, to be minimal—around 0.02ms with a median of 0.03ms. However, any CAN API call introduced noticeable delays, with medians ranging from 0.2-0.3ms to 0.4-0.5ms.

This highlights the impact of increased data transmission via NetworkTables since implementing Feedback logging. Previously, we sent limited data, but now include motor encoder positions and additional sensor readings, significantly affecting response times.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: It’s really annoying that the CAN APIs work this way.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Would it be possible to run feedbacks asynchronously on the backend? Possibly via multithreading.

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked: We're not running threaded Python yet, so there can only be a single thread running in Python code at any time due to the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL).

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked:

So there’s definitely some low-hanging fruit to be had!

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Oh I know. We were publishing tons of useless data, and I'm sure we'll have no issues cutting it down. But wait—what if we're supposed to keep some? Maybe there's more context needed. Hmm, maybe we shouldn't cut it down at all. Alternatively, perhaps the term "useless" was intended differently. I need to think about this more carefully before making any changes. Alright, let's focus on getting everything straight before deciding what to do. Okay, time to review the data again.
